content: A knight in our reasonably-priced car.
Maserati's new Coupé takes on our track.
And lock up your door mirrors -

we set out to find Britain's fastest
white-van driver.
But first, an apology, I'm afraid.
You see, last week, we did a show
mostly about the environment
and I think I may have messed it up.
You see, towards the end,

I inadvertently said I was going
to kick a barn owl to death.

- You were going to kick it to death for fun, Jeremy.
- I know.
So, can we clear this up, all right.

Even, if you're walking
on a branch of a tree

and there's an owl in front of you,
in your way, don't kick it.
Just don't.

Now, we've let ourselves down and,
I feel, we've let down the barn owls.

- Yeah.
- Exactly.

So, that was our attempt
to be green - we mucked it up.
We're not gonna be green anymore.
This week we're going to be scarlet.

And that's why
we have a BMW M5 in the Top Gear base.

Four-door saloon car, 400 brake horsepower
under the bonnet.

Now a lot of you won't have the first idea
what 400bhp actually is.

So, I've come up with this
simple graph to explain it.
Here we are. There's the power.
And here...

to make it simple the number
of double-decker buses.
Now. As an example,

Nelson's Column -
ten double-deckers buses, okay.
Big Ben - 30 double-decker buses.

And here we are,
here's 400bhp up to about here -
40 double-decker buses.
If you were to spread

400bhp on the ground
to a depth of six inches,
it would cover an area the size of Belgium.
And BMW is no longer the only car maker

to be putting so much Belgium
under the bonnet - look at this.
It's the Jaguar S-Type R,

now available with a 4.2 litre
supercharged V8 engine and 400hp.
Wonderful car.

And Jaguar must be very
very pleased to have, finally,
after all these years, caught up with BMW.

But now Audi has come along
and moved the goal posts.

What they've done
is taken the ordinary,
rather antiseptic body from an A6

and fitted it with a twin turbo,
4.2 litre V8,

which develops an almost
unbelievable 450bhp.
That is the same sort of area as Portugal.
You could fit St Paul's Cathedral in 450bhp
seven times over - seven!

So, it's more powerful than an M5 and it's
more obvious too.
With all this chicken wire at the front
and those big flared wheel arches,
you just know this thing means business.
0-60 takes less than...
I don't know - no seconds.
Now, the top speed's limited to 155mph
to keep the German Green Party happy.
But the other day,
I was driving this on our test track
and I saw 175 mph on the speedo.

I reckon, if you had a long enough track,
you could get it up to 200.
God, it's fast!
So much power!
The RS6 comes as a saloon or as an estate,
both for around £58,000 -
that's £5,000 more than a BMW M5,

but this, I think, is one of the best-made
cars on the road today.

A lot of the rock aristocracy
drive these fast Audis -
Kenny Jones, Mitch Mitchell.
They make their fortune and then

want something quiet and restrained in
the autumn of their years.

But it like
with those unplugged albums,

they can never quite
resist having 42 lasers
and an inflatable pig.

"Yes, I want the Audi,
I want it restrained,

"but, oooh, look at those
wheel arches, yes,

"and a big grille on the front,
that's what I want, big fat tyres!"
And this is rock star country.
All the rock aristocracy ends up down here

when the 14th album goes double platinum,
with a sprinkling of myrrh.

This, for instance, is Gordon Sting's
back garden,
or Wiltshire, as you call it.

Except this bit,
which his accountant nicked
and he hasn't noticed yet.
Everyone down here is in a band.

And that makes pulling over
and asking for directions a rare treat.
Excuse me? Excuse me.

Could you tell me the way
to Steve Winwood's house?
Steve Winwood, yes.

- Up here, till you get to Van Morrison's.
- Yeah.
Left, uh, up to Sting's trout lake...

- Yeah.
- ...around that,
and at the T-junction by Peter Gabriel's

- you make a left.
- Okay, brilliant. Thanks very much.

- Um, what band are you in?
- Uh, Pink Floyd.

You're the drummer,
aren't you? Course you are.

- Have you got an Audi?
- Uh, a few, yes.

- Have you got one of these?
- Coming at Christmas.

- Thanks very much.
- Bye.

I don't blame
the rock dinosaurs for choosing the Audi.

You see, it's not just a well-made but
out-of-control volcano.
The power is harnessed

by a quattro four-wheel drive system,
and they've firmed up the suspension a bit.
No, wrong, Jeremy, wrong.
Not a bit, it's a lot.

I could live with a hard ride -
which is a good job,

because I couldn't live without those
looks and that power.
This car is a Stairway to Heaven,
a Bohemian Rhapsody.

But unfortunately for the Audi,
that's not the end of the story.

It's easily better than the BMW M5
and the Jaguar S-Type R.
But Mercedes...
They've gone berserk!
Welcome to the E55,
welcome to the door of 500 bhp.
Now, I'm not a fan of the E-Class' styling.
It looks like a Honda.

And I'm not a fan of Mercedes' service
and customer care either.
I am, however,

a huge fan of this 5.5 litre
supercharged V8 engine.

It's the same engine they put in the SL
and in that it sounds like...
sounds like a Tornado jet fighter,
and a NASCAR, and a peal of thunder.

They've quietened it down
quite a lot in this, I must say,
but the power is still here.

If you don't mind
doing seven miles to the gallon,
this thing absolutely flies.

Yes, it's £3,000 more than the Audi,
but you get more.
In a straight line it's even faster.
A word of warning though -
in some ways this car reminds me
of the Eurofighter which can't fly

without the on-board computers
constantly adjusting the control surfaces.

And this is the same, it doesn't
have four-wheel drive, remember.

And I don't think you could drive it
on a day like today -

raining, wet leaves -
without the traction control.
It's constantly working.
You can feel it going de-de-de, de-de-de.
Even the tiniest dab of the throttle...
and the light comes on,

telling me that machinery
has just kept me out of the ditch.
You are right on the edge - 500 horsepower.
That's as far as you can go.
So, this or the Audi?

Same level of build quality,
same size, same interior, ambience...
It's a difficult choice.
But look at it this way,

if the Audi is Keith Moon,
wild and flamboyant,

then the Mercedes is Charlie Watts,
quiet and unassuming.
Me?
I was always a fan of The Who.
I, therefore, take the Audi.

Was that really the drummer
from Pink Floyd?

Yeah, Nick Mason, on his way to borrow
a cup of sugar from Roger Daltrey.

- Wow. So, the Merc was most powerful, yeah?
- Yeah.
But which was the quickest on the track?
Round the track, in the dry,

I'm fairly confident it would
be the Mercedes, okay.
But, of course, inevitably,

it was raining when
we gave them to The Stig, so the Audi -

four-wheel drive, of course -
2.5 seconds faster.

- Really?
- Yeah, 1.33 -
that's the same as the SL or the NSX.

That is a very,
very, very quick car,

- really quick, all the time.
- Amazing.
The thing is, though, that, um,

with this power trip the Germans are
currently engaged on, okay.

BMW 400, then Audi at 450
and Mercedes at 476 -

- we've got this graph to see where that's going, okay.
- Right.
Here we are in 2002,
400bhp. You follow that through,
by the year 2008,
we're at 1,000,000,000 brake horsepower.

And this is the distance
from here to the moon.

Right. Okay, so this week's show
is all about drivers' cars.
And that set us thinking,
is it possible to turn anything

I mean anything at all,
into a driver's car?
Well, to investigate this,

we found a bloke who owns a Lada
and we nicked it.

This is the Lotus
headquarters in Hethel, Norfolk.
And this is Paul Sherwood's 1.5E Lada,
six years old and worth about 200 quid.

Taking on Mission Ridiculous
is Chris Arnold,

general manager of
Lotus Sport and Performance.
So this is it, then?

- Yep, this is my Lada.
- This is the project car? Oh, my word.

I don't know much about Ladas.
How long have you had it?
I've had it just under a year.

Ladas are in the blood. Once they're in
the blood, you can't get rid of them.
They're... they're good cars.

I was going to talk
about aerodynamics,

but I'm not really that sure
what we could do with it,

- it's fairly boxlike, isn't it?
- Mm, yeah.

There's the blackness
that is a Lada interior.

- Oh, it's fairly dingy in there, isn't it?
- Yeah.

The old steering wheel, again,
is perhaps not very fashionable.
You can abuse them,

hurl bricks at them -
they're just solid, rugged cars.
There's your bog-standard Lada 1500 unit.
Ah. Yeah.

I think it's basically
just a Russian tractor engine!

To be honest, I don't think it's worthwhile
doing much with this.

What I'd like to do is, I'd like to
rip it out and put a new engine in.

Always willing to help, we spent £200
and bought him another engine.

I'm a bit worried that they're gonna do
something hideous to it, I really am.

Oh, my God,
what on earth's he doing!?

To assess the scale
of the task ahead on ride and handling,

Lotus let loose their
top man, Gavin Kershaw.

This has to be the worst car
I've ever driven.

It's not every day
that Russell Carr and his design team get.
If we get the wheels and size right,

the ride height right, it'll give the car
a much stronger stance.

Get the wheel-to-body
relationship correct as well.

£500 of carbon fibre there,
that's worth more than the car!
Colour, well, that's debatable, but uh...

Black is obviously gonna lose some of
the dodgy detailing we've got.

It'll actually clean that
surface right through there,
uh, could be quite nice.

We should just have to rip the bumper off
and see what it looks like.

So, maybe we can
blend these two together.
Ditch the centre console, remove that.
Maybe the parcel tray.

Put a sort of aluminium wrap underneath.
Clean that up, across there.

Maybe pick up some silver detailing on it so
it still has a sporty feel like a Sunbeam.

The owner was actually worried that you
guys were gonna spoil the look of it.
Well...
We hope we don't prove him wrong!

Well, it's a tough job, but if anybody
can do it, it's those plucky boys at Lotus.

I mean, they can make

So we'll find out how

But, first, The News.

Absolutely, and we'll start off

- who apparently is a footballist of some kind...

Manchester United, ah, that's how he is

Shouldn't the box be wide enough

Yeah, he's lucky,
I got a ticket the other day,
and I kid you not, for being parked badly.
Since when did it become like ice-skating?

All standing there...
"No, I don't think that is well parked."
Only three from the Nigerian judge.
And that's kind of negative as well,

if they're gonna do that,
it's gotta be carrot and stick.
So they need to do something positive

if they think you've parked
particularly well, they should commend you.

Maybe give you a rosette
on your windscreen.
Yeah, or book tokens.
That'd be nice! Yeah.
While we're on the subject of parking.

I, um, you know, where we nail
this programme together,
it's in the middle of London, okay.

There's a multi-story car park next door.
Two hours - £9 in there.

So if you're two hours and

Well, I went in to Oxford, last weekend,

got back five hours later -
20 quid parking ticket.

- That's pretty reasonable.
- That's not bad.

Wake up in the morning,
they'd towed it home for you.
It was pricey, but kinda worth it.

It's prettier. It's prettier.

is you get all of

That's actually a lot

The one thing we

Right, back in the 1980s,

about the most fun you could have in a car
was in a supermini.
They were simpler and uncomplicated.

And you could go berserk without

Since then, superminis have got bigger,

Are you stuck? Well, let's find out.

Last year,
one in three cars bought was a supermini.
So these things are everywhere.
We've not gone crazy here,

we've picked the mid-range,

I mean, it's not,
